docs.snippet: Few states rode Senator Barack Obama's coattails as much as Colorado. Hosts to the Democratic National Convention in August, Coloradoans continued their shift to the left thanks to the growing number of younger and Hispanic voters in the state. Se...
docs.lead_paragraph: Few states rode Senator Barack Obama's coattails as much as Colorado. Hosts to the Democratic National Convention in August, Coloradoans continued their shift to the left thanks to the growing number of younger and Hispanic voters in the state. Senator Obama handily beat Senator John McCain to become the third Democratic presidential candidate to win the state since Harry S. Truman. Representative Mark Udall, a Democrat, won the Senate seat left vacant by the retirement of Wayne Allard, a Republican. Mr. Udall beat Bob Schaffer, a Republican, with 52 percent of the vote.
docs.abstract: Rep Mark Udall, Democrat, defeats Republican Bob Schaffer to win Colorado Senate seat left vacant by retirement of Republican Sen Wayne Allard; in Congressional elections, Democrat Jared Polis defeats Republican Scott Starin and Democrat Betsy Markey defeats incumbent Republican Marilyn Musgrave; voters reject amendment to state Constitution that would have defined human life as beginning at moment of fertilization; Barack Obama wins state, 53-46 percent; tallies (S)

docs.snippet: As Vermont continues its change from a historically conservative state to one of the most liberal, its voters showed once again their lack of concern with party labels.     Gov. Jim Douglas, a Republican moderate, won easy re-election over an inde...
docs.lead_paragraph: As Vermont continues its change from a historically conservative state to one of the most liberal, its voters showed once again their lack of concern with party labels. Gov. Jim Douglas, a Republican moderate, won easy re-election over an independent, Anthony Pollina, and a Democrat, Gaye Symington, who finished virtually tied for a distant second place.
docs.abstract: Vermont Republican Gov Jim Douglas wins re-election over Independent Anthony Pollina and Democrat Gaye Symington; Democratic Rep Peter Welch wins without Republican opposition; Barack Obama wins state, 67-32 percent; tally (S)

docs.snippet: It should come as no surprise that liberal Massachusetts would vote overwhelmingly for Barack Obama, or that the state returned Senator John Kerry, a Democrat, to Washington by a margin of more than two to one in a race against Jeff Beatty, a Repu...
docs.lead_paragraph: It should come as no surprise that liberal Massachusetts would vote overwhelmingly for Barack Obama, or that the state returned Senator John Kerry, a Democrat, to Washington by a margin of more than two to one in a race against Jeff Beatty, a Republican security specialist whose campaign never seemed to gain traction. This will be Mr. Kerry's fifth term. While there was little suspense in the electoral contests, ballot measures drew strong interest. Voters overwhelmingly approved a proposal to decriminalize the possession of small amounts of marijuana, 70 percent to 30 percent.
docs.abstract: Democratic Sen John Kerry wins re-election over Jeff Beatty in Massachusetts; voters reject measure to reduce and ultimately eliminate state income tax; approve proposal to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana; Barack Obama wins state, 62-36 percent; tallies (M)

docs.snippet: Travel | This would be a tonic for the travel industry if only the President-elect's many admirers could afford it -- for "to see all the places connected to Obama's life story, you'd have to visit three countries, six time zones and six states." ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Travel | This would be a tonic for the travel industry if only the President-elect's many admirers could afford it -- for "to see all the places connected to Obama's life story, you'd have to visit three countries, six time zones and six states," an article notes. [Associated Press]
docs.abstract: Travel | This would be a tonic for the travel industry if only the President-elect's many admirers could afford it -- for "to see all the places connected to Obama's life story, you'd have to visit three countries, six time zones and six states." [Associated Press]

docs.snippet: A 1995 interview with Barack Obama finds the candidate focused on the same themes he is today....
docs.lead_paragraph: The blogger who calls himself (or herself) Existenz at Old Man McCain has unearthed a 1995 TV interview in which Barack Obama promotes his first book. "One can see that Barack Obama was already starting to think about issues of poverty and race in a political context," writes Existenz. "He mentions the 'race card,' Rev. Wright, his absent father, and his white grandmother -- all issues that would become oh so relevant here in 2008. It was also rather tragic to hear him mention his mother, since we know she would succumb to ovarian cancer later that year."
docs.abstract: A 1995 interview with Barack Obama finds the candidate focused on the same themes he is today.

docs.snippet: Intense analysis of Barack Obama's myth and reality has already begun....
docs.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama's pre-announcement of his 2008 presidential campaign took the form of a five-minute video biography. In his own video analysis, John Dickerson of Slate dissects the ad, pointing out how the announcement emphasizes the Illinois senator's biography, his popularity and his experience as an underdog and de-emphasizes his short Senate record. One black-and-white photo, showing the young Obama in a black turtleneck and leather jacket, Dickerson says, "appears to be the cover picture from his first jazz album."
docs.abstract: Intense analysis of Barack Obama's myth and reality has already begun.
